carousel.caption: See what the Timpanogos Grotto is all about.
Check out what the grotto has been up to and check for any upcoming events or trips.
See some of our featured caves as well as any closed caves.
Contact us with any comments or questions that you have.

faq.header: How do I obtain a list of caves in my area?
faq.text: The best way to find caves in your area is by becoming a member of the grotto. As a member, you will have access to caving trips, meetings, and our member forums where you can introduce yourself and meet other cavers in your area. As a rule, cave locations are not published in order to help protect the cave.

faq.header: How do I become a member?
faq.text: Click the "Become a Member" tab on our about us page. Likewise, you can also come to any meeting and pay dues there to become a member. Dues are $15/year.

The term 'grotto' is synonymous with 'club' or 'chapter', as in a chapter of a larger organization. The Timpanogos Grotto primarily serves the Central Utah area, and is one of around 250 chapters of the National Speleological Society.

faq.header: What is the National Speleological Society?
faq.text: The National Speleological Society (NSS) is a non-profit membership organization dedicated to the scientific study of caves and karst; protecting caves and their natural contents through conservation, ownership, stewardship, and public education; and promoting responsible cave exploration and fellowship among those interested in caves. [taken from the NSS mission statement] The NSS is our parent organization. Almost all of us are also members of the NSS.

faq.header: How do I obtain a list of caves in my area?
faq.text: The best way to find caves in your area is by becoming a member of the grotto. As a member, you will have access to caving trips, meetings, and our member forums where you can introduce yourself and meet other cavers in your area. As a rule, cave locations are not published in order to help protect the cave.

faq.header: Can't I just visit the caves on my own? Why do I have to join a group to learn their locations?
faq.text: Caves that get abused become closed to everyone, including even the most responsible, veteran cavers. People new to caving may unknowingly abuse caves; examples include touching formations or creatures, walking in protected areas, or not using pads when rigging rope. There are even some people who intentionally abuse caves, leaving behind trash, graffiti, and even human waste. We subscribe to a "leave no trace" philosophy, and do our best to protect our underground treasures from both accidental and intentional harm. This includes only sharing locations with those who we trust to also cherish and protect them.

faq.header: What if I don't know what gear to get, how to climb rope, etc?
faq.text: This is one of the major benefits to joining a grotto! The Timpanogos Grotto offers vertical classes, access to an entire library of caving books, publications, trips for all skill levels, and monthly educational meetings. All of our members were once new, too. We're happy to help you figure out what will work, offer guidance, and point you in the right direction. Our members range from first-time cavers to seasoned veterans and everything in between.

No. Caving is an inherently dangerous activity. People are injured and die every year. The caving we do does not involve guard rails, paved paths, and stairs. The kind of caving we do is NOT a tour. This is why we take safety seriously. Also, caving is not for everyone. We are happy to get you started, but we do not hold your hand - everyone is ultimately responsible for themselves. We try to help make it as safe as possible, but caving is not simply hiking underground. If we do not think you can handle yourself safely or if you cannot follow conservation guidelines, you will not be invited on or allowed to join trips. It is not just your life at risk, it is our lives, too.

recentTrips.reportTitle: Main Drain: Neffs Inlet Break Out
recentTrips.reportText: Miles and miles of cave found

Elliot Stahl, Dave Stahl, and myself set out to Gypsy Cave located on the SCCI Charles B. Henson Johnson’s Crook preserve in order to execute a dome climb to promising leads located high in the back wall in the main entrance. There are a total of 3 possible leads in this area of the cave. Two appear to be entrances into developed canyon passage located approximately 65ft up the face of the wall. The third lead is located in the ceiling of this room, approximately another 40ft above the two aforementioned leads.  Upon arrival, we determined that the far right lead, which appeared to have an entrance to a well developed canyon passage, would be our first priority which provided the cleanest route up the wall to access. With Elliot belaying me, I set out to climb the wall, making 14 placements with removable gear, and reached the lead in just under two hours. The canyon passage went on for approximately 15ft, coming to a constriction between flowstone. Another 15ft of passage was gained after passing through the constriction before the passage terminated. The entrance to this lead will be the site for the new belay station from which the final climb to the lead in the ceiling will be accomplished. As such, we set rigging from the first lead, using 3/8 inch x 3” long ss bolts, with two rebelays in order to avoid large, loose boulders and sharp rocks, back to the main passage floor. Once the rigging was in place, the route was cleaned of all removable gear.

Future objectives

We will return to the cave to complete the final climb to the lead in the ceiling. After evaluating its potential for continuing passage, we will then rappel from this lead to the final third lead, located parallel to the first lead, offset approximately 20ft to the left. In the event that no significant passage is found, hangers will be removed from the rebelays set and bolts pounded through and covered.

Little Brush Creek Cave, Uintah County, Utah
On trip: Hannah Lieffring, Jason Weyland, Andy Armstrong, Eric Richards, Justin Calder
After having done a lot of traveling and finally heading back to Utah, Hannah and I were thinking of our
good friends Andy and Bonny Armstrong. We reached out to them to see if they would be free for any
caving while we would be in Utah, and we were able to set up a trip to Little Brush Creek Cave which he
states being his favorite cave in Utah. Unfortunately Bonny wasn’t able to come along. But by the time
the trip rolled around, Eric Richards and Justin Calder were on board.
After talking with Andy, we made a plan that we wanted to visit the black stream in the cave. Hannah
and I made a trip there last November, and were stopped by towering mud banks that blocked the
passage. Now, more prepared for what we would encounter, we were finally getting back there.
We drove out on Saturday morning to do nearby Toothbrush cave with Eric and Justin, as Andy couldn’t
arrive until Sunday, and checked a few leads that were given to us by Dave Herron. These caves have the
potential to flood dramatically every summer, making the caves very dynamic by opening or closing
passages. We were to check to see if any of those had opened in the many years since they were last
checked. We scouted some potential high leads that would later need bolt climbs done, and checked
some known dig leads that were mapped years ago to see if they had opened up. The big room where
the high leads were was really impressive with wintry ice stalagmites and a massive column of ice that
mimicked flowstone. Eric and Justin took up the dig leads, while Hannah and I traveled back to the
higher parts of the cave to check some on some leads on the map. While there, we encountered
numerous amazing ice crystals that weren’t unlike gypsum flowers in shape. Both parties being
unsuccessful and chilled to the core with the below freezing cave temps, we all went back to the main
room and started our climb out of the forty foot drop just inside the cave. After derigging and
snowshoeing back to the car, we discovered that we had parked a little to far in the snow and had
gotten stuck. In order to get out, we had to get a little creative with some webbing, an old rope and
Justin’s new Tacoma. About an hour later, we were out and on our way to get some celebratory Taco
Bell.
Sunday morning, we all gathered at the Split Mountain Motel before piling into the vehicles heading
back into the Uinta mountains. Our plan was to navigate to the black stream and push as far as we
could. The unfinished, minimal detailed map leads me to believe there is a lot more virgin cave to be
found as there is a question mark at the end of what appears to be giant borehole passage. It looks as if
the last people there just turned around and never came back to push further, and that got me really
intrigued. It was about three hours of travel through the cave to make it to the black stream cutoff,
which is just an overflow hall for when the black stream floods and pours into the main cave stream
known as the white stream. We waded into the water and started heading up stream to where we last
saw the mud bank in November. The stream goes underneath the mudbank where it becomes
impassible with choked rocks and breakdown, so the only way on is over. With the support of five
people, I was able to stem and climb my way up to the top and anchor a handline for the group. It was
the first time any of us had been to this point in the cave, and the giant, gaping borehole with the sound
of rushing water only added to our excitement. Eric and Justin, with an early callout time for them,
opted to turn around at this point. Afterall, it’s a part of the cave that not many get to see, and making it

this far had satisfied their need for underground time. After saying our goodbyes, Andy, Hannah and I
continued on up stream. We traveled upstream for a while longer, encountering waist deep pools which
drenched us and filled our boots, eventually coming to what I had heard might be there but hadn’t been
confirmed – a full-on swim through snow melt water that went on for an unknown length as it snuck out
of sight around a corner. Since none of us had packed our wetsuits, this was the end for us. A wet travel
back through an already cold cave with frozen water near the entrance and snow outside didn’t sound
as enticing as you might think. Another day we will bring even more gear into the cave to go further. We
opted to turn around, and once back at the black stream cutoff decided to see what was in store for us
down stream. The map had the end of this being marked as sumped (to my understanding never having
been dove for any of you cave divers out there), with many question marks identifying side leads along
the way. Hannah and I had only traveled just a small way downstream during our last trip here, so these
passages were again new to the three of us. We followed the twisting, turning stream passage wading
into more waist deep pools, negotiating over breakdown, and down incredible waterfalls all while
dramatic, high walls (often with gaping holes in the side. Remember those question marks on the map?)
often leading high and out of site into darkness showed us the way. To our surprise, and joy I might add,
this went on for much longer than any of us had really expected. Very often, cave maps simply don’t do
much for showing the massive scale or length of the cave as we experience it in person. Soon enough,
the ceiling dropped as though to meet the water but left a ongoing two feet of air space with the floor
also dropping and turning it into another swimmer. This is it, the end of the map going downstream,
where it is marked as “sump.” Shining our lights into the low air space, it seemed as though the cave
goes on to where no person has been before. I anticipate that it does. Hannah, feeling braver than us,
started to wade into the deep water just to “test the waters.” Soon, the tall sandy banks beneath the
water and beneath her feet gave way, sending her into the cold, snowmelt water a lot faster than she
had planned. Feeling like this too would need a wet suit and future caving trip, we retreated up stream
until we again met the black stream cutoff. As this was the only flowing water in the cave that we
encountered today, we drank as much as we could, filled our bottles, had a snack, and started the long
journey out. We returned to what is known as the Cascade Room and braced ourselves (or maybe it was
just me) for the long crawl ahead. Round trip, Andy estimated for the day that we had crawled hands
and knees over rocks and cobble for just under 3,000ft. This is by far my least favorite part of the cave,
and I’ve done it so, so many times now. After stemming over frozen plunge pools and crawling through
mazes of log jams, we finally emerged from the cave with just the last sliver of daylight. Wanting to take
advantage of the light, we changed into our dry, warm clothes and started the snowshoe back to the
cars, where we had parked more carefully this time. During the drive back to town, we hypothesized and
threw ideas around of where this passage goes or what that lead does or where these passages might
connect when really only future trips will help us answer those questions.

Bill Koerschner and Bob Alderson are the best cavers in the expedition. Done. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.
